p: Early detection, prevention, and treatment of complications caused by chronic HCV infection may improve the outcomes of infected kidney transplant recipients [ 16]. Screening for HCV infection is done using a serological assay that detects antibodies against HCV (anti-HCV). After a positive anti-HCV test, HCV RNA testing should be performed. A negative result is considered a resolved HCV infection (or a false-positive antibody test) [ 17].
